Question_1.Context: Zirconium phosphate (ZrP) nanoparticles are known to influence the properties of nanofibres when added during the electrospinning process.
Question_1.Question: What effect does the addition of zirconium phosphate (ZrP) nanoparticles have on the diameter of polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofibres during electrospinning?
Question_1.Source: Addition of metal oxide such as zirconium phosphate decreases the diameter and smooths on the polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofibres as observed by the SEM techniques.

Question_2.Context: The morphology and conductivity of nanofibres can be influenced by the addition of certain nanoparticles.
Question_2.Question: What is the effect of zirconium phosphate on the morphology of modified PAN nanofibres?
Question_2.B: It does not change their morphology
Question_2.Source: The modified PAN nanofibres with zirconium phosphate nanoparticles showed the surface smoothness with the reduced diameters of 100–150 nm.

Question_3.Context: Conductivity is a critical property of nanofibres, especially when used in applications such as fuel cells.
Question_3.Question: How does zirconium phosphate affect the conductivity of PAN and PAN-Nafion zirconium phosphate nanofibres?
Question_3.D: Increases conductivity only in the presence of Nafion
Question_3.Source: The conductivity of PAN and PAN-Nafion zirconium phosphate nanofibres was more improved when compared to that of the plain PAN nanofibres as observed under electrochemical measurements.

Question_4.Context: Thermal gravimetric analysis is used to study the thermal properties of materials, including their stability and decomposition temperatures.
Question_4.Question: What does thermal gravimetric analysis reveal about the thermal degradation properties of PAN-Nafion/ZrP nanofibres compared to plain PAN nanofibres?
Question_4.A: PAN-Nafion/ZrP nanofibres degrade at a lower temperature
Question_4.B: PAN-Nafion/ZrP nanofibres have similar thermal properties
Question_4.C: PAN-Nafion/ZrP nanofibres are thermally less stable
Question_4.D: PAN-Nafion/ZrP nanofibres are thermally more stable
Question_4.Source: The TGA results show that the initial weight loss occurred at 150 °C in PAN-Nafion/ZrP nanofibres, with a little weight loss... PAN-Nafion/ZrP nanofibres are thermally more stable than PAN and PAN/ZrP nanofibres as they have a higher decomposition temperature.

Question_5.Context: Electrospinning is a technique used to create nanofibres, and the process can be influenced by various parameters.
Question_5.Question: Which parameter is not typically varied to produce nanofibres with different fineness and surface morphology during electrospinning?
Question_5.Source: Moreover, by varying viscosity, surface tension, molecular structure, molecular weight, solution concentration, solvent structure, additive and operational conditions such as rotating speed, spinning head diameter, nozzle diameter and nozzle-collector distance of the same solution may produce a nanofibre web with the various fineness, orientation and surface morphology.

Question_6.Context: Nafion® membrane is known for its high proton conductivity and chemical resistance, which can be altered by blending with other polymers.
Question_6.Question: What is the effect of blending Nafion® with other polymers like PAN on its proton conductivity?
Question_6.C: Has no effect on proton conductivity
Question_6.D: Makes the membrane less resistant to chemicals
Question_6.Source: Electrospinning Nafion® solution increases the proton conductivity of nanofibres with the reduced nanometre scale.

Question_7.Context: Polyacrylonitrile (PAN) is a polymer that can be electrospun into nanofibres and has certain desirable properties for specific applications.
Question_7.Question: Which property is not associated with polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofibres?
Question_7.A: Good resistance to many organic solvents
Question_7.B: Poor thermal stability at higher temperatures
Question_7.Source: Moreover, PAN also maintains a good thermal stability at a higher temperature of 130 °C and has a good resistance to many organic solvents.

Question_8.Context: Zirconium oxide (ZrO2) has several properties that make it a useful material in various applications.
Question_8.Question: Which property is not characteristic of zirconium oxide (ZrO2)?
Question_8.Source: Zirconium oxide (ZrO2) has several properties that make it a useful material. These properties include high density, hardness, electrical conductivity, wear resistance, high fracture toughness, low thermal conductivity and relatively high dielectric constant.

Question_9.Context: Zirconium phosphates (ZrPs) are inorganic cation-exchange materials with high thermal stability and other features beneficial for certain applications.
Question_9.Question: What feature of zirconium phosphate contributes to increasing conductivity in polymer membranes?
Question_9.A: High proton mobility on the surface of its particles
Question_9.B: Low proton mobility on the surface of its particles
Question_9.C: High electron mobility on the surface of its particles
Question_9.D: Low electron mobility on the surface of its particles
Question_9.Source: Zirconium phosphate has the features of increasing conductivity due to high proton mobility on the surface of its particles and good water retention.

Question_10.Context: The addition of nanoparticles to a polymer matrix can influence the thermal and electrochemical properties of the resulting composite material.
Question_10.Question: What is the impact of impregnating a polymer membrane with zirconium phosphate nanoparticles?
Question_10.A: Decreases the power density of the membrane
Question_10.B: Increases the methanol permeability of the membrane
Question_10.C: Reduces the methanol permeability of the membrane while maintaining high power density
Question_10.D: Has no effect on the methanol permeability or power density
Question_10.Source: The reduced methanol permeability of the polymer membrane, while maintaining a high power density, is obtained by impregnating it with zirconium phosphate.
